title: healthbR Maintenance Guide
text: document captures operational knowledge maintaining healthbR package: data source details, monitoring, triage procedures, add new modules.

title: healthbR Maintenance Guide
text: DATASUS FTP can slow weekdays 9-17 BRT; weekend/night downloads 5-10x faster. DATASUS FTP occasionally drops connections mid-transfer; package retries exponential backoff. DATASUS FTP requires ftp_use_epsv=FALSE curl; EPSV mode fails silently. SI-PNI CSV files ~1.4 GB ZIP / ~6 GB CSV ; downloading requires patience disk space. SI-PNI CSV uses semicolon delimiter latin1 encoding (UTF-8). SI-PNI CPNI (coverage) uses comma decimal separator COBERT field. SISAB portal (sisab.saude.gov.br) frequently “Em manutencao”; package uses relatorioaps-prd backend directly. VIGITEL page uses JavaScript rendering; package scrapes direct download links HTML. SIDRA API rate limit; batch requests short pauses calls. SIH/SIA SEXO codes differ SIM: SIH uses 0/1/3 (Ignorado/Masculino/Feminino), SIM uses M/F/. DBC files DBF compressed PKWare DCL implode; package includes C code decompression. iconv(x, = "ASCII//TRANSLIT") segfaults Windows R; package uses chartr() accent removal. utils::unzip() fails Portuguese characters ZIP filenames Windows; PowerShell Expand-Archive used fallback.

title: healthbR Maintenance Guide
text: check-endpoints.yaml GitHub Actions workflow runs 1st month (manual trigger). probes 14 endpoints fails unreachable, triggering GitHub email notification. run manually:
code: gh workflow run check-endpoints.yaml

title: healthbR Maintenance Guide
text: Follow triage checklist: temporary? Re-run workflow. DATASUS FTP intermittent outages lasting minutes hours. server completely ? Check DATASUS/IBGE services also affected. Government servers sometimes planned maintenance windows (especially weekends). URL move? Browse parent FTP directory see path structure changed. DATASUS historically reorganized directories (e.g., 200801_ prefix SIH). schema change? Download sample file check column names dictionary. DATASUS occasionally adds/removes columns years. new year rollover? Around March-April year, DATASUS publishes prior-year data. Preliminary directories may appear final data available. Open issue label data-source describing endpoint failed, last working, error details workflow log.

title: healthbR Maintenance Guide
text: Target ~2 releases per year. Time releases around DATASUS annual data publications (typically March/April prior-year data). Always run devtools::check(cran = TRUE) submission; target 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes. Test R-devel, R-release, R-oldrel (R-CMD-check workflow covers ).

title: healthbR Maintenance Guide
text: Identify data source: URL, file format, update frequency, geographic/temporal coverage. {module}_data() — main data retrieval function. {module}_dictionary() — variable dictionary (data coded categories). {module}_variables() {module}_{type}s() — list available file types categories. uf — 2-letter state abbreviation (data per-UF). year — 4-digit year(s). month — 1-12 (data monthly). cache — logical, default TRUE. parse — logical, default TRUE (smart type parsing). col_types — named list type overrides, default NULL. lazy — logical, default FALSE (lazy evaluation). backend — c("arrow", "duckdb") lazy queries. utils-cache.R — .cache_parquet(), .cache_read(), .try_lazy_cache(), .data_return(). utils-download.R — .ftp_download(), .http_download_resumable(), .multi_download(). utils-parallel.R — .map_parallel(). utils-parse.R — .parse_columns(), .build_type_spec(). Unit tests mock downloads (run without network). Integration tests guarded skip_if_no_integration(). Aim 50+ unit tests covering validation, caching, parsing, error handling. Add vignette vignettes/{module}.Rmd. Add probe .github/workflows/check-endpoints.yaml. Update MAINTENANCE.md — add module registry table note quirks. Update DESCRIPTION — bump version, add new dependencies Imports/Suggests. Run devtools::check(cran = TRUE) — must pass 0/0/0.

title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS
text: ANS (Agencia Nacional de Saude Suplementar) Brazil’s regulatory agency private/supplementary health insurance (planos de saude). open data portal provides data beneficiaries, consumer complaints, operator financial statements.

title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS
code: # beneficiaries (default) ans_years()  # complaints ans_years(type = "complaints")  # financial statements ans_years(type = "financial")

title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS
code: ans_info()

title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS
text: Beneficiary data provides consolidated counts health plan enrollees broken operator, municipality, sex, age group, plan type, . file covers one state (UF) one month.

title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS
code: # Acre, December 2023 ac <- ans_data(year = 2023, month = 12, uf = "AC") ac

title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS
code: # first quarter 2024, two states ne <- ans_data(year = 2024, month = 1:3, uf = c("CE", "PE"))  # full year (month = NULL downloads all 12 months) ac_2023 <- ans_data(year = 2023, uf = "AC")

title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS
code: ans_data(   year = 2023, month = 12, uf = "AC",   vars = c("CD_OPERADORA", "SG_UF", "TP_SEXO",            "DE_FAIXA_ETARIA", "QT_BENEFICIARIO_ATIVO") )

code: # complaints filed in 2022 nip <- ans_data(year = 2022, type = "complaints") nip  # multiple years nip_multi <- ans_data(year = 2020:2023, type = "complaints")

code: # Q1 2023 fin_q1 <- ans_data(year = 2023, type = "financial", quarter = 1)  # all 4 quarters of 2023 fin_2023 <- ans_data(year = 2023, type = "financial")  # specific quarters fin_q12 <- ans_data(year = 2023, type = "financial", quarter = 1:2)

title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS
text: operator registry separate snapshot (time-series), uses function:

code: # beneficiaries variables (default) ans_variables()  # complaints variables ans_variables(type = "complaints")  # financial variables ans_variables(type = "financial")  # search across variables ans_variables(search = "operadora") ans_variables(search = "beneficiario")

what: Example: beneficiaries by state and plan type
title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS
code: # December 2023, all states ben <- ans_data(year = 2023, month = 12)  # active beneficiaries by state and coverage type ben |>   group_by(SG_UF, COBERTURA_ASSIST_PLAN) |>   summarize(     total = sum(as.integer(QT_BENEFICIARIO_ATIVO), na.rm = TRUE),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   arrange(desc(total))

code: # Q4 2023 financial data fin <- ans_data(year = 2023, type = "financial", quarter = 4)  # join with operator registry for names ops <- ans_operators()  fin |>   filter(grepl("^41", CD_CONTA_CONTABIL)) |>  # revenue accounts   group_by(REG_ANS) |>   summarize(     revenue = sum(as.numeric(VL_SALDO_FINAL), na.rm = TRUE),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   left_join(     ops |> select(REGISTRO_OPERADORA, Razao_Social),     by = c("REG_ANS" = "REGISTRO_OPERADORA")   ) |>   arrange(desc(revenue)) |>   head(10)

title: Supplementary Health Data with ANS

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: ANVISA (Agencia Nacional de Vigilancia Sanitaria) Brazil’s health surveillance agency responsible regulating medicines, health products, food, cosmetics, sanitizers, tobacco, pesticides. open data portal provides CSV files product registrations, post-market surveillance (pharmacovigilance, hemovigilance, technovigilance), controlled substance sales (SNGPC).

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: Use anvisa_types() see available types:
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)  anvisa_types()

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: download current snapshot registry database. year month parameter needed.

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: require year parameter optionally month parameter.

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: Download complete registry medicines approved ANVISA:
code: medicines <- anvisa_data(type = "medicines")  # explore the data nrow(medicines) names(medicines)  # filter active medicines active <- medicines |>   filter(SITUACAO_REGISTRO == "ATIVO")  # count by therapeutic class active |>   count(CLASSE_TERAPEUTICA, sort = TRUE)

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
code: devices <- anvisa_data(type = "medical_devices")  # count by risk class devices |>   count(CLASSE_RISCO, sort = TRUE)

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
code: food <- anvisa_data(type = "food") cosmetics <- anvisa_data(type = "cosmetics")

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
code: # only keep product name and active ingredient med_slim <- anvisa_data(   type = "medicines",   vars = c("NOME_PRODUTO", "PRINCIPIO_ATIVO", "SITUACAO_REGISTRO") )

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: Pesticide monographs list authorized active ingredients maximum residue limits (LMR):
code: pesticides <- anvisa_data(type = "pesticides")  # search for a specific substance anvisa_variables(type = "pesticides", search = "substancia")  # substances authorized for coffee coffee <- pesticides |>   filter(NO_CULTURA == "Cafe")

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: Adverse events related blood transfusions:
code: hemo <- anvisa_data(type = "hemovigilance")  # count by reaction type hemo |>   count(TIPO_REACAO_TRANSFUSIONAL, sort = TRUE)  # count by state hemo |>   count(UF_NOTIFICACAO, sort = TRUE)

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: Adverse events related medical devices:
code: techno <- anvisa_data(type = "technovigilance")  # count by notification type techno |>   count(TIPO_NOTIFICACAO, sort = TRUE)

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: Drug/vaccine adverse event reports split three linked datasets sharing IDENTIFICACAO_NOTIFICACAO key:
code: # notifications (patient info + event summary) notif <- anvisa_data(type = "vigimed_notifications")  # medicines involved meds <- anvisa_data(type = "vigimed_medicines")  # adverse reactions (MedDRA coded) reactions <- anvisa_data(type = "vigimed_reactions")  # link notifications to reactions linked <- notif |>   select(IDENTIFICACAO_NOTIFICACAO, SEXO, IDADE_MOMENTO_REACAO, GRAVE) |>   inner_join(reactions, by = "IDENTIFICACAO_NOTIFICACAO")  # most common reactions linked |>   count(PT, sort = TRUE) |>   head(20)

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: SNGPC (Sistema Nacional de Gerenciamento de Produtos Controlados) tracks sales controlled substances (psychotropics, narcotics) pharmacies across Brazil.

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
code: # download January 2020 data sngpc_jan <- anvisa_data(type = "sngpc", year = 2020, month = 1)  # top prescribed controlled substances sngpc_jan |>   count(DS_PRINCIPIO_ATIVO, sort = TRUE) |>   head(10)  # sales by state sngpc_jan |>   count(SG_UF_VENDA, sort = TRUE)

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
code: # download Q1 2020 (Jan-Mar) sngpc_q1 <- anvisa_data(type = "sngpc", year = 2020, month = 1:3)  # monthly trend sngpc_q1 |>   count(month, name = "sales")

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
code: # compounded (manipulated) controlled substances manip <- anvisa_data(type = "sngpc_compounded", year = 2020, month = 1)  # most common active ingredients manip |>   count(NO_PRINCIPIO_ATIVO, sort = TRUE) |>   head(10)

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: large SNGPC queries spanning many months, use lazy evaluation defer computation:
code: # lazy query (requires arrow package) lazy_sngpc <- anvisa_data(   type = "sngpc", year = 2020, month = 1:12,   lazy = TRUE )  # filter and collect only what you need result <- lazy_sngpc |>   filter(SG_UF_VENDA == "SP") |>   collect()

title: Health Surveillance Data with ANVISA
text: Use anvisa_variables() see available variables type:
code: # all medicines variables anvisa_variables(type = "medicines")  # search across descriptions anvisa_variables(type = "hemovigilance", search = "paciente")  # SNGPC variables anvisa_variables(type = "sngpc")

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: Censo Demografico (Demographic Census) main source population denominators Brazil, essential calculating mortality rates, disease incidence, epidemiological indicators. healthbR package provides direct access Census population data via IBGE SIDRA API, covering:

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: censo_info(2022)

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: common use case: getting population state denominator health indicators.
code: # total population by state, Census 2022 pop_state <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state") pop_state

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: # population by sex, Brazil level pop_sex <- censo_populacao(   year = 2022,   variables = "sex",   territorial_level = "brazil" ) pop_sex

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: # population by age and sex pop_age_sex <- censo_populacao(   year = 2022,   variables = "age_sex",   territorial_level = "brazil" ) pop_age_sex

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: # population by race, 2022 pop_race <- censo_populacao(   year = 2022,   variables = "race",   territorial_level = "state" ) pop_race

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: years censuses, IBGE publishes annual population estimates serve denominators:
code: # population estimates 2015-2021 estimates <- censo_estimativa(   year = 2015:2021,   territorial_level = "state" ) estimates

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: typical epidemiological workflow combines mortality data (SIM) Census denominators:
code: # step 1: get population denominator pop_2010 <- censo_populacao(   year = 2010,   variables = "total",   territorial_level = "state" )  # step 2: suppose you have mortality data (from SIM or other source) # deaths_by_state <- sim_data(year = 2010) |> count(state)  # step 3: calculate crude mortality rate # mortality_rate <- deaths_by_state |> #   left_join(pop_2010, by = "state") |> #   mutate(rate_per_100k = (n / population) * 100000)

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: Census module includes catalog SIDRA tables organized theme:
code: # list all available tables censo_sidra_tables()  # filter by theme censo_sidra_tables(theme = "disability") censo_sidra_tables(theme = "indigenous")  # search by keyword censo_sidra_search("quilombola") censo_sidra_search("saneamento")

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: full flexibility, use censo_sidra_data() query Census table:
code: # population by race from table 9605 pop_race_raw <- censo_sidra_data(   table = 9605,   territorial_level = "state",   year = 2022,   variable = 93,   classifications = list("86" = "allxt") ) pop_race_raw

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: # compare population across census years pop_2010 <- censo_populacao(year = 2010, territorial_level = "brazil") pop_2022 <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "brazil")  # or use estimates for intercensitary years pop_series <- censo_estimativa(   year = 2001:2021,   territorial_level = "brazil" ) pop_series

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
text: CNES (Cadastro Nacional de Estabelecimentos de Saude) Brazil’s national health facility registry, maintained Ministry Health DATASUS. contains monthly snapshots registered health establishments, professionals, beds, equipment, . healthbR package provides access CNES data DATASUS FTP:

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
text: CNES data organized 13 file types:

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: cnes_info()

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: # all establishments in Acre, January 2023 ac_jan <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC") ac_jan

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: leitos <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "LT") leitos

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: prof <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "PF") prof

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
text: month parameter controls monthly snapshots download:
code: # single month jan <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # first semester sem1 <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1:6, uf = "AC")  # specific months q1_q3 <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = c(3, 6, 9), uf = "AC")  # all 12 months (default when month = NULL) full_year <- cnes_data(year = 2023, uf = "AC")

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: # only key variables (faster) cnes_data(   year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC",   vars = c("CNES", "CODUFMUN", "TP_UNID", "VINC_SUS") )

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: # all coded variables cnes_dictionary()  # facility types (22 categories) cnes_dictionary("TP_UNID")  # administrative sphere cnes_dictionary("ESFERA_A")

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: # get facility type labels tp_unid_labels <- cnes_dictionary("TP_UNID") |>   select(code, label)  # join to data ac_facilities <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC") |>   left_join(tp_unid_labels, by = c("TP_UNID" = "code")) |>   rename(facility_type = label)  ac_facilities |>   count(facility_type, sort = TRUE)

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: ac <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC")  sus_by_type <- ac |>   filter(VINC_SUS == "1") |>   count(TP_UNID, sort = TRUE)  # add labels tp_labels <- cnes_dictionary("TP_UNID") |>   select(code, label)  sus_by_type |>   left_join(tp_labels, by = c("TP_UNID" = "code"))

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
text: Combine CNES bed data Census population:
code: # step 1: count beds by UF (December snapshot) beds <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 12, type = "LT") |>   group_by(uf_source) |>   summarize(total_beds = n(), .groups = "drop")  # step 2: population from Census 2022 pop <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state")  # step 3: calculate beds per 1,000 inhabitants # beds_rate <- beds |> #   left_join(pop, by = ...) |> #   mutate(beds_per_1000 = (total_beds / population) * 1000) |> #   arrange(desc(beds_per_1000))

what: Example: tracking facility counts over time
title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: # quarterly snapshots for Sao Paulo sp_quarterly <- cnes_data(   year = 2020:2023,   month = c(3, 6, 9, 12),   uf = "SP" )  facility_trend <- sp_quarterly |>   group_by(year, month) |>   summarize(     total = n(),     sus_linked = sum(VINC_SUS == "1", na.rm = TRUE),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   arrange(year, month)  facility_trend

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
text: CNES data monthly per-state, full downloads can involve many files: 1 UF, 1 month, 1 type = 1 file 1 UF, 12 months = 12 files 27 UFs, 12 months = 324 files per type Use uf month limit downloads. Start single UF month explore data scaling .

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
code: # parsed types (default) ac <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC") class(ac$COMPETEN)  # Date  # raw character columns ac_raw <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC", parse = FALSE)

title: Health Facility Registry with CNES
text: Downloaded data cached locally faster future access: arrow package installed, data cached Parquet format. can also use lazy evaluation:
code: # check cache status cnes_cache_status()  # clear cache if needed cnes_clear_cache() # lazy query (requires arrow) cnes_lazy <- cnes_data(year = 2023, uf = "AC", lazy = TRUE) cnes_lazy |>   filter(VINC_SUS == "1", month == 1L) |>   select(CNES, CODUFMUN, TP_UNID) |>   collect()

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: healthbR package provides access eight DATASUS information systems, covering mortality, live births, hospital admissions, outpatient production, notifiable diseases, health facility registry, vaccination data, primary care coverage: seven modules share infrastructure: DBC decompression: .dbc files (compressed DBF) decompressed internally using vendored C code – external dependencies required. FTP download: files fetched ftp.datasus.gov.br automatic retry exponential backoff. Cache: downloaded data cached locally Parquet (arrow installed) .rds format. Consistent API: every module exposes *_years(), *_info(), *_variables(), *_dictionary(), *_data(), *_cache_status(), *_clear_cache().

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: module provides set helper functions. quick tour using SIM example: pattern works sinasc_*(), sih_*(), sia_*(), sinan_*(), cnes_*(), sipni_*().
code: # available years sim_years() #> [1] 1996 1997 1998 ... 2023  # module information (data source, key variables, usage tips) sim_info()  # list all variables with descriptions sim_variables()  # search for a specific variable sim_variables(search = "causa")  # data dictionary with category labels sim_dictionary("SEXO")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: SIM (Sistema de Informacoes sobre Mortalidade) contains individual death records based Declaracao de Obito ().

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: # all deaths in Acre, 2022 obitos_ac <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC") obitos_ac

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: cause parameter filters underlying cause death (CAUSABAS) using CID-10 prefix matching:
code: # deaths from acute myocardial infarction (I21) obitos_iam <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", cause = "I21")  # all cardiovascular deaths (chapter I) obitos_cardio <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", cause = "I")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: obitos_ac <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  obitos_ac |>   mutate(chapter = substr(CAUSABAS, 1, 1)) |>   count(chapter, sort = TRUE)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: SINASC (Sistema de Informacoes sobre Nascidos Vivos) contains individual live birth records Declaracao de Nascido Vivo (DN).

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: nasc_ac <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC") nasc_ac

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: anomaly parameter filters CODANOMAL variable using CID-10 prefix matching:
code: # births with any congenital anomaly (chapter Q) anomalias <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", anomaly = "Q")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: nasc_ac <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  nasc_ac |>   mutate(peso_num = as.numeric(PESO)) |>   filter(!is.na(peso_num), peso_num > 0) |>   mutate(weight_group = case_when(     peso_num < 1500 ~ "Very low (<1500g)",     peso_num < 2500 ~ "Low (1500-2499g)",     peso_num < 4000 ~ "Normal (2500-3999g)",     TRUE            ~ "High (>=4000g)"   )) |>   count(weight_group)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: SIH (Sistema de Informacoes Hospitalares) contains individual hospital admission records AIH (Autorizacao de Internacao Hospitalar). Unlike SIM SINASC, data organized monthly.

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: # admissions in Acre, January 2022 intern_jan <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC") intern_jan

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: SIH data monthly – one file per UF per month. Use month control months download:
code: # single month sih_data(year = 2022, month = 6, uf = "AC")  # first semester sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1:6, uf = "AC")  # all 12 months (default when month = NULL -- downloads 12 files per UF) sih_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: diagnosis parameter filters principal diagnosis (DIAG_PRINC) using CID-10 prefix matching:
code: # respiratory admissions (chapter J) resp <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")  # pneumonia specifically (J12-J18) pneum <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC",                   diagnosis = c("J12", "J13", "J14", "J15", "J16", "J17", "J18"))

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: intern <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  intern |>   mutate(chapter = substr(DIAG_PRINC, 1, 1)) |>   count(chapter, sort = TRUE)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: SIA (Sistema de Informacoes Ambulatoriais) contains outpatient production records. Like SIH, data monthly, SIA also 13 file types covering different categories outpatient care.

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: # outpatient production in Acre, January 2022 (default type = "PA") ambul_jan <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC") ambul_jan  # different file type: high-cost medications med <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "AM")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: # filter by SIGTAP procedure code (prefix match on PA_PROC_ID) consult <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", procedure = "0301")  # filter by CID-10 diagnosis (prefix match on PA_CIDPRI) resp <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: ambul <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  ambul |>   mutate(proc_group = substr(PA_PROC_ID, 1, 2)) |>   count(proc_group, sort = TRUE)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: SINAN (Sistema de Informacao de Agravos de Notificacao) contains individual notification records 31 compulsorily notifiable diseases. Unlike DATASUS modules, SINAN files national (one file per disease per year, covering Brazil).

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: SINAN covers 31 diseases. Use sinan_diseases() see available codes:
code: sinan_diseases() #> # A tibble: 31 x 3 #>    code  name                      description #>    <chr> <chr>                     <chr> #>  1 DENG  Dengue                    Dengue #>  2 CHIK  Chikungunya               Febre de Chikungunya #>  3 ZIKA  Zika                      Zika virus #>  4 TUBE  Tuberculose               Tuberculose #>  ...  # search for a specific disease sinan_diseases(search = "sifilis")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: # dengue notifications, 2022 (default disease) dengue <- sinan_data(year = 2022)  # tuberculosis notifications, 2020-2022 tb <- sinan_data(year = 2020:2022, disease = "TUBE")  # select specific variables sinan_data(year = 2022, disease = "DENG",            vars = c("DT_NOTIFIC", "CS_SEXO", "NU_IDADE_N",                     "ID_MUNICIP", "CLASSI_FIN"))

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: Since files national, filter UF download:
code: dengue <- sinan_data(year = 2022)  # filter by state of notification dengue_sp <- dengue |>   filter(SG_UF_NOT == "35")  # Sao Paulo (IBGE code)  # or by municipality dengue_rio <- dengue |>   filter(substr(ID_MUNICIP, 1, 2) == "33")  # Rio de Janeiro state

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: dengue <- sinan_data(year = 2022, disease = "DENG")  dengue |>   filter(CLASSI_FIN %in% c("1", "5")) |>  # confirmed cases   mutate(month = substr(DT_NOTIFIC, 4, 5)) |>   count(month, sort = TRUE)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: CNES (Cadastro Nacional de Estabelecimentos de Saude) national registry health facilities Brazil. Like SIH SIA, data organized monthly (one file per type/UF/month), 13 file types covering different aspects registry.

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: # establishments in Acre, January 2023 estab <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # hospital beds leitos <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "LT")  # health professionals prof <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "PF")

what: Example: facility types in a state
title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: estab <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC")  estab |>   count(TP_UNID, sort = TRUE) |>   left_join(     cnes_dictionary("TP_UNID") |> select(code, label),     by = c("TP_UNID" = "code")   )

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: SI-PNI (Sistema de Informacao Programa Nacional de Imunizacoes) provides vaccination data two sources: FTP (1994–2019): Aggregated data dose counts coverage rates per municipality/vaccine/age group. Plain .DBF files (DBC-compressed). OpenDataSUS API (2020–2025): Individual-level microdata one row per vaccination dose (~47 fields per record). sipni_data() transparently routes correct source based requested year.

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: # FTP: doses applied in Acre, 2019 (default type = "DPNI") doses_ac <- sipni_data(year = 2019, uf = "AC") doses_ac  # FTP: vaccination coverage cob_ac <- sipni_data(year = 2019, type = "CPNI", uf = "AC")  # API: individual-level microdata, Acre, January 2024 micro_ac <- sipni_data(year = 2024, uf = "AC", month = 1) micro_ac

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
code: doses <- sipni_data(year = 2019, uf = "AC")  doses |>   group_by(IMUNO) |>   summarize(total_doses = sum(as.numeric(QT_DOSE), na.rm = TRUE)) |>   arrange(desc(total_doses)) |>   left_join(     sipni_dictionary("IMUNO") |> select(code, label),     by = c("IMUNO" = "code")   )

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: key strength healthbR ability combine data different DATASUS modules Census denominators single workflow. three practical examples.

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: Calculate crude cardiovascular mortality rate per 100,000 population:
code: # step 1: count cardiovascular deaths in Sao Paulo, 2022 obitos_cardio <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "SP", cause = "I") n_obitos <- nrow(obitos_cardio)  # step 2: get population denominator from Census 2022 pop_sp <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state") |>   filter(grepl("Paulo", territorial_unit))  # step 3: calculate rate taxa_mortalidade <- n_obitos / pop_sp$population * 100000 taxa_mortalidade

what: Live births to deaths ratio (SINASC + SIM)
title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: Compare number live births deaths state:
code: # births and deaths in Acre, 2022 nascimentos <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC") obitos <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  razao <- nrow(nascimentos) / nrow(obitos) razao #> ratio > 1 means more births than deaths (population growth)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: Compare volumes costs respiratory care (CID-10 chapter J) hospital outpatient settings:
code: # hospital admissions for respiratory diseases, January 2022 intern_resp <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")  # outpatient production for respiratory diseases, January 2022 ambul_resp <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")  # compare volumes n_internacoes <- nrow(intern_resp) n_ambulatorial <- nrow(ambul_resp)  # compare costs custo_intern <- sum(as.numeric(intern_resp$VAL_TOT), na.rm = TRUE) custo_ambul <- sum(as.numeric(ambul_resp$PA_VALAPR), na.rm = TRUE)  tibble::tibble(   setting = c("Hospital (SIH)", "Outpatient (SIA)"),   records = c(n_internacoes, n_ambulatorial),   total_cost_brl = c(custo_intern, custo_ambul) )

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: DATASUS modules cache downloaded data automatically. arrow package installed, data saved Parquet format (fast compact); otherwise, .rds used fallback.
code: # install arrow for optimized caching (recommended) install.packages("arrow")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: module provides *_cache_status() *_clear_cache():
code: # check what is cached sim_cache_status() sih_cache_status() sia_cache_status()  # clear cache for a specific module sim_clear_cache()

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: Use uf download states need instead 27 (SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, CNES). Use month (SIH, SIA, CNES) limit monthly downloads. Downloading full year states requires 324 files per module (27 UFs x 12 months). Use vars keep variables need, reducing memory usage. SIM SINASC annual (one file per UF per year), full-year download 27 files. SINAN files national (one file per disease per year), downloads fast files can large. SIH, SIA, CNES monthly, full-year download 324 files per type. SIA CNES 13 file types – always filter type, uf, month. SI-PNI FTP annual plain .DBF files (one per type/UF/year, 1994–2019). API data (2020+) per-UF/year; use month limit months.

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES, SI-PNI, and SISAB
text: DATASUS TabNet – online tabulation tool DATASUS data DATASUS FTP – public FTP server raw data files CID-10 (ICD-10) – International Classification Diseases, 10th revision SIGTAP – procedure code table SUS (SIA/SIH)

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: healthbR provides easy access Brazilian public health data directly R. package downloads, caches, processes data official sources (Ministry Health, IBGE, DATASUS), returning clean, analysis-ready tibbles following tidyverse conventions. package currently supports 13 data sources organized two groups: Surveys (IBGE / Ministry Health) DATASUS (Ministry Health FTP)

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: see available data sources glance: modules follow consistent API pattern: *_years() / *_info() – metadata available years *_variables() / *_dictionary() – variable names category labels *_data() – download load data *_cache_status() / *_clear_cache() – cache management
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr) list_sources() #> # A tibble: 13 x 5 #>    source  name                         description                    years       status #>    <chr>   <chr>                        <chr>                          <chr>       <chr> #>  1 vigitel VIGITEL                      Telephone survey on chronic... 2006-2024   available #>  2 pns     PNS - Pesquisa Nacional ...  National health survey (IBGE) 2013, 2019  available #>  ...

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: VIGITEL telephone survey conducted annually 27 state capitals, monitoring risk protective factors chronic non-communicable diseases. Key variables include pesorake (survey weight), diab (diabetes), hart (hypertension), fumante (smoker), imc (BMI).
code: # check available years vigitel_years()  # download data for a single year df <- vigitel_data(year = 2024)  # explore the data dictionary dict <- vigitel_dictionary()  # list variables vigitel_variables() # weighted prevalence of diabetes by city using srvyr library(srvyr)  df |>   as_survey_design(weights = pesorake) |>   group_by(cidade) |>   summarize(     prevalence = survey_mean(diab == 1, na.rm = TRUE),     n = unweighted(n())   )

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: PNS provides comprehensive data health conditions, lifestyle, healthcare access ~100,000 households.
code: # microdata pns <- pns_data(year = 2019)  # explore modules and variables pns_modules(year = 2019) pns_dictionary(year = 2019)  # tabulated indicators from SIDRA API (no download needed) pns_sidra_search("diabetes") pns_sidra_data(table = 4487, territorial_level = "state", year = 2019)

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: PNAD Continua includes health-related supplementary modules disability, housing conditions, primary health care (APS), household characteristics.
code: # list available modules pnadc_modules()  # download disability supplement defic <- pnadc_data(module = "deficiencia", year = 2019, quarter = 1)  # explore variables pnadc_variables(module = "deficiencia")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: POF (Household Budget Survey) contains data food insecurity (EBIA), individual food consumption, anthropometry, health expenses. See vignette("pof-health-data") detailed walkthrough.
code: # list available registers pof_registers(year = 2018)  # food consumption microdata consumo <- pof_data(year = 2018, register = "consumo_alimentar")  # food insecurity scale (EBIA) morador <- pof_data(year = 2018, register = "morador")  # variable dictionary for a specific register pof_dictionary(year = 2018, register = "morador")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: Census module queries IBGE SIDRA API population denominators, essential calculating mortality rates, incidence, epidemiological indicators. See vignette("censo-denominadores") epidemiological examples.
code: # population by state, sex, and age group (2022 Census) pop <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state")  # intercensitary population estimates (for years between censuses) est <- censo_estimativa(year = 2020, territorial_level = "state")  # query any Census SIDRA table directly censo_sidra_search("populacao") censo_sidra_data(table = 9514, territorial_level = "brazil", year = 2022)

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SIM contains individual death records death certificates (CID-10, 1996+).
code: # deaths in Acre, 2022 obitos <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  # filter by cause of death (CID-10 prefix) obitos_cardio <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", cause = "I")  # explore variables and categories sim_variables() sim_dictionary("CAUSABAS")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SINASC contains individual birth records including birth weight, gestational age, prenatal care, congenital anomalies.
code: # births in Acre, 2022 nascimentos <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  # filter by congenital anomaly (CID-10 prefix) anomalias <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", anomaly = "Q")  sinasc_variables() sinasc_dictionary("PARTO")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SIH contains hospital admission records (AIH) diagnosis, procedures, length stay, costs. Data organized monthly.
code: # admissions in Acre, January 2022 internacoes <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # filter by principal diagnosis (CID-10 prefix) intern_resp <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")  sih_variables() sih_dictionary("DIAG_PRINC")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SIA covers outpatient production data 13 file types (BPA, APAC, RAAS).
code: # outpatient production in Acre, January 2022 (default type: PA) ambulatorial <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # high-cost medications (APAC) medicamentos <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "AM")  # filter by procedure or diagnosis sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", procedure = "0301") sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "E11")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SINAN contains individual notification records 31 notifiable diseases including dengue, tuberculosis, chikungunya, zika, hepatitis, syphilis, others. Files national (per-state), download covers Brazil given disease year. Since SINAN files national, filter state download using SG_UF_NOT (UF notification) ID_MUNICIP (municipality code):
code: # list available diseases sinan_diseases()  # search for a specific disease sinan_diseases(search = "dengue")  # dengue notifications, 2022 dengue <- sinan_data(year = 2022, disease = "DENG")  # tuberculosis, 2020-2022 tb <- sinan_data(year = 2020:2022, disease = "TUBE")  # explore variables and categories sinan_variables() sinan_dictionary("EVOLUCAO") dengue |>   filter(SG_UF_NOT == "35")  # Sao Paulo

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: CNES national registry health facilities, covering hospitals, clinics, primary care units, health establishments. Data organized monthly 13 file types. See vignette("datasus-modules") cross-module analysis examples.
code: # see all file types cnes_info()  # establishments in Acre, January 2023 estab <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # hospital beds leitos <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "LT")  # health professionals prof <- cnes_data(year = 2023, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "PF")  # explore variables and categories cnes_variables() cnes_dictionary("TP_UNID")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SI-PNI data comes two sources: FTP (1994–2019) aggregated dose counts coverage rates, OpenDataSUS API (2020–2025) individual-level microdata (one row per vaccination dose). sipni_data() routes transparently based requested year.
code: # module overview sipni_info()  # FTP: doses applied in Acre, 2019 (aggregated) doses <- sipni_data(year = 2019, uf = "AC")  # FTP: vaccination coverage cobertura <- sipni_data(year = 2019, type = "CPNI", uf = "AC")  # API: microdata for Acre, January 2024 micro <- sipni_data(year = 2024, uf = "AC", month = 1)  # explore variables for each data source sipni_variables()                  # FTP DPNI variables sipni_variables(type = "API")      # API microdata variables sipni_dictionary("IMUNO")          # FTP dictionary

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SISAB provides aggregated coverage indicators primary care (Atencao Primaria) via public REST API. Unlike DATASUS modules, FTP download .dbc decompression needed.
code: # module overview sisab_info()  # APS coverage by state, January 2024 cobertura <- sisab_data(year = 2024, month = 1)  # national total, full year 2023 sisab_data(year = 2023, level = "brazil")  # oral health coverage sisab_data(year = 2024, type = "sb", month = 6)  # municipality level for Sao Paulo sisab_data(year = 2024, level = "municipality", uf = "SP", month = 1)  # explore variables sisab_variables() sisab_variables(type = "sb")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: modules cache downloaded data automatically avoid repeated downloads. Install arrow optimized Parquet caching (recommended): Cache management works across modules:
code: install.packages("arrow") # check what is cached sim_cache_status() vigitel_cache_status()  # clear a module's cache sim_clear_cache()  # use a custom cache directory (e.g., for temporary use) sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", cache_dir = tempdir())

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: healthbR’s real power comes combining data across modules. example, calculating mortality rates requires deaths (SIM) population (Censo):
code: library(dplyr)  # deaths by state deaths <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC") |>   count(name = "deaths")  # population by state pop <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state") |>   filter(nivel_territorial_codigo == "12")  # Acre  # crude mortality rate deaths$deaths / pop$valor * 100000

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: vignette("pof-health-data") – Analyzing food security nutrition POF vignette("censo-denominadores") – Population denominators epidemiology vignette("datasus-modules") – SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA, SINAN, CNES depth Package website GitHub repository

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: POF (Pesquisa de Orçamentos Familiares) household budget survey conducted IBGE investigates household expenditures, living conditions, nutritional profiles Brazilian population. conducted partnership Ministry Health. healthbR package provides access POF microdata focus health-related data:

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: Use pof_info() see health modules available edition:

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: POF edition contains multiple data registers. Use pof_registers() see :
code: # all registers pof_registers("2017-2018")  # only health-related registers pof_registers("2017-2018", health_only = TRUE)

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: downloading data, can browse available variables:
code: # list all variables in the domicilio register pof_variables("2017-2018", "domicilio")  # search for food security variables pof_variables("2017-2018", search = "ebia")  # search for weight-related variables pof_variables("2017-2018", "morador", search = "peso")

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: EBIA (Escala Brasileira de Insegurança Alimentar) available 2017-2018 edition domicilio register. variable V6199 contains food security classification.

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: domicilio <- pof_data("2017-2018", "domicilio")

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: EBIA classifies households four levels:

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: domicilio <- domicilio |>   mutate(     ebia = factor(       V6199,       levels = 1:4,       labels = c(         "Food security",         "Mild insecurity",         "Moderate insecurity",         "Severe insecurity"       )     )   )  # frequency table domicilio |>   count(ebia) |>   mutate(pct = n / sum(n) * 100)

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: proper population estimates, use survey design:
code: library(srvyr)  domicilio_svy <- pof_data("2017-2018", "domicilio", as_survey = TRUE)  # add EBIA categories domicilio_svy <- domicilio_svy |>   mutate(     ebia = factor(       V6199,       levels = 1:4,       labels = c(         "Food security",         "Mild insecurity",         "Moderate insecurity",         "Severe insecurity"       )     )   )  # weighted prevalence domicilio_svy |>   group_by(ebia) |>   summarize(     prevalence = survey_mean(na.rm = TRUE, vartype = "ci"),     n = unweighted(n())   )

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: # food insecurity by state domicilio_svy |>   group_by(UF, ebia) |>   summarize(     prevalence = survey_mean(na.rm = TRUE, vartype = "ci"),     n = unweighted(n())   ) |>   filter(ebia == "Severe insecurity") |>   arrange(desc(prevalence))

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: consumo_alimentar register contains detailed personal food intake data subsample. data available 2008-2009 2017-2018 editions.

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: consumo <- pof_data("2017-2018", "consumo_alimentar")

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: # total daily caloric intake per person consumo |>   group_by(COD_UPA, NUM_DOM, NUM_UC, COD_INFORMANTE) |>   summarize(     total_kcal = sum(ENERGIA_KCAL, na.rm = TRUE),     total_protein = sum(PROTEINA, na.rm = TRUE),     total_carb = sum(CARBOIDRATO, na.rm = TRUE),     total_fat = sum(LIPIDIO, na.rm = TRUE),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   summarize(     mean_kcal = mean(total_kcal, na.rm = TRUE),     mean_protein = mean(total_protein, na.rm = TRUE),     mean_carb = mean(total_carb, na.rm = TRUE),     mean_fat = mean(total_fat, na.rm = TRUE)   )

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: despesa_individual register contains individual expenses, including health-related spending medications, health insurance, medical consultations.

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: despesas <- pof_data("2017-2018", "despesa_individual")

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: Health-related expenses can identified product group codes:
code: # explore expense categories despesas |>   count(QUADRO) |>   arrange(desc(n))

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: many analyses need combine data multiple registers. Use household identifier variables (COD_UPA, NUM_DOM, NUM_UC) merge:
code: # download morador (demographic data) and domicilio (household data) morador <- pof_data("2017-2018", "morador") domicilio <- pof_data("2017-2018", "domicilio")  # merge: add household-level EBIA to individual-level data morador_ebia <- morador |>   left_join(     domicilio |> select(COD_UPA, NUM_DOM, NUM_UC, V6199),     by = c("COD_UPA", "NUM_DOM", "NUM_UC")   ) |>   mutate(     ebia = factor(       V6199,       levels = 1:4,       labels = c(         "Food security",         "Mild insecurity",         "Moderate insecurity",         "Severe insecurity"       )     )   )  # food insecurity by age group morador_ebia |>   mutate(age_group = cut(V0403, breaks = c(0, 5, 12, 18, 30, 60, Inf))) |>   count(age_group, ebia) |>   group_by(age_group) |>   mutate(pct = n / sum(n) * 100)

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: POF conducted different years, data structure may vary. Use pof_info() check available edition:
code: # check health modules by edition pof_info("2017-2018")  # EBIA + food consumption pof_info("2008-2009")  # anthropometry + food consumption pof_info("2002-2003")  # expenses only

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: POF data files large. healthbR caches downloaded files locally download : arrow package installed, data cached Parquet format faster loading:
code: # check cached files pof_cache_status()  # clear cache if needed pof_clear_cache() # install arrow for optimized caching (recommended) install.packages("arrow")

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: POF official page (IBGE) POF 2017-2018 Food Security publication POF 2017-2018 Food Consumption publication srvyr package documentation

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
text: SINAN (Sistema de Informacao de Agravos de Notificacao) Brazil’s national notifiable disease surveillance system, managed Ministry Health DATASUS. records individual notification forms compulsory-notification diseases. healthbR package provides access SINAN microdata DATASUS FTP:

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
code: sinan_info()

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
text: SINAN covers 31 notifiable diseases. Use sinan_diseases() browse : Common disease codes:
code: # all available diseases sinan_diseases()  # search by name or code sinan_diseases(search = "dengue") sinan_diseases(search = "sifilis") sinan_diseases(search = "tuberculose")

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
code: dengue_2022 <- sinan_data(year = 2022) dengue_2022

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
code: tb <- sinan_data(year = 2020:2022, disease = "TUBE") tb

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
code: # only key variables (faster and less memory) dengue_key <- sinan_data(   year = 2022,   disease = "DENG",   vars = c("DT_NOTIFIC", "CS_SEXO", "NU_IDADE_N",            "CS_RACA", "ID_MUNICIP", "CLASSI_FIN") )

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
code: sinan_variables() sinan_variables(search = "sexo") sinan_variables(search = "municipio")

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
text: SINAN files national (per-state). filter geographic unit, use SG_UF_NOT (UF notification) ID_MUNICIP (municipality code) columns download:
code: # filter by UF dengue_sp <- sinan_data(year = 2022) |>   filter(SG_UF_NOT == "35")  # 35 = Sao Paulo  # filter by municipality dengue_rj_capital <- sinan_data(year = 2022) |>   filter(ID_MUNICIP == "330455")  # Rio de Janeiro capital

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
code: # all coded variables sinan_dictionary()  # specific variable sinan_dictionary("CS_SEXO") sinan_dictionary("EVOLUCAO") sinan_dictionary("CLASSI_FIN")

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
text: SINAN publishes final (definitive) preliminary data. default, sinan_years() returns final years: Preliminary data (2023–2024) may still revised Ministry Health.
code: # final data only (default) sinan_years(status = "final")  # preliminary data sinan_years(status = "preliminary")  # both sinan_years(status = "all")

what: Example: confirmed dengue cases by month
title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
code: dengue <- sinan_data(year = 2022, disease = "DENG") |>   filter(CLASSI_FIN %in% c("1", "5")) |>  # confirmed cases    mutate(month = as.integer(format(DT_NOTIFIC, "%m")))  cases_by_month <- dengue |>   count(month) |>   arrange(month)  cases_by_month

what: Example: tuberculosis by sex and age group
title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
code: tb <- sinan_data(year = 2022, disease = "TUBE")  # decode age: 4th digit means years tb_age <- tb |>   filter(CLASSI_FIN == "1") |>   mutate(     age_unit = substr(NU_IDADE_N, 1, 1),     age_value = as.integer(substr(NU_IDADE_N, 2, 3)),     age_years = ifelse(age_unit == "4", age_value, NA_integer_),     age_group = cut(age_years,                     breaks = c(0, 15, 30, 45, 60, Inf),                     labels = c("<15", "15-29", "30-44", "45-59", "60+"),                     right = FALSE)   )  tb_age |>   filter(!is.na(age_group)) |>   count(CS_SEXO, age_group) |>   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = CS_SEXO, values_from = n)

what: Example: incidence rate with Census denominators
title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
text: Combine SINAN data Census population calculate incidence rates:
code: # step 1: confirmed dengue by UF dengue_uf <- sinan_data(year = 2022, disease = "DENG") |>   filter(CLASSI_FIN %in% c("1", "5")) |>   count(SG_UF_NOT, name = "cases")  # step 2: population from Census 2022 pop <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state")  # step 3: calculate incidence rate per 100,000 # incidence <- dengue_uf |> #   left_join(pop, by = ...) |> #   mutate(rate_100k = (cases / population) * 100000) |> #   arrange(desc(rate_100k))

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
text: default, sinan_data() parses columns appropriate types (dates, integers):
code: # parsed types (default) dengue <- sinan_data(year = 2022, disease = "DENG") class(dengue$DT_NOTIFIC)  # Date class(dengue$NU_ANO)      # integer  # raw character columns (backward-compatible) dengue_raw <- sinan_data(year = 2022, disease = "DENG", parse = FALSE)  # override specific columns dengue_custom <- sinan_data(   year = 2022,   col_types = list(DT_NOTIFIC = "character") )

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
text: Downloaded data cached locally faster future access: arrow package installed, data cached Parquet format faster loading. can also use lazy evaluation:
code: # check cache status sinan_cache_status()  # clear cache if needed sinan_clear_cache() # lazy query (requires arrow) dengue_lazy <- sinan_data(year = 2022, disease = "DENG", lazy = TRUE) dengue_lazy |>   filter(CLASSI_FIN == "1") |>   select(DT_NOTIFIC, CS_SEXO, NU_IDADE_N, ID_MUNICIP) |>   collect()

title: Notifiable Disease Surveillance with SINAN
text: SINAN official page (DATASUS) Notifiable diseases list (Ministry Health) SIM vignette mortality data Census vignette population denominators

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
text: SI-PNI (Sistema de Informacao Programa Nacional de Imunizacoes) Brazil’s national immunization information system, managed Ministry Health. tracks vaccination doses applied coverage rates across country. healthbR package provides access SI-PNI data two sources: sipni_data() automatically routes correct source based requested year.

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
code: sipni_info()

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
text: default type downloads aggregated dose counts (1994–2019):
code: # doses applied in Acre, 2019 ac_doses <- sipni_data(year = 2019, uf = "AC") ac_doses

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
code: # vaccine codes sipni_dictionary("IMUNO")  # dose types sipni_dictionary("DOSE")  # age groups sipni_dictionary("FX_ETARIA")

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
text: CPNI type provides coverage rates per municipality:
code: # vaccination coverage in Acre, 2019 ac_coverage <- sipni_data(year = 2019, type = "CPNI", uf = "AC") ac_coverage

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
text: years 2020 later, SI-PNI provides individual-level microdata (one row per vaccination dose). type parameter ignored years:
code: # microdata for Acre, January 2024 ac_micro <- sipni_data(year = 2024, uf = "AC", month = 1) ac_micro

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
code: # DPNI variables (FTP) sipni_variables()  # CPNI variables (FTP) sipni_variables(type = "CPNI")  # API/CSV variables (2020+) sipni_variables(type = "API")  # search sipni_variables(search = "dose")

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
text: years >= 2020, month separate ~1.4 GB national CSV file. Use month select specific months: FTP data (1994–2019), month parameter ignored FTP files annual.
code: # single month jan <- sipni_data(year = 2024, uf = "AC", month = 1)  # first quarter q1 <- sipni_data(year = 2024, uf = "AC", month = 1:3)  # all 12 months (default, downloads ~17 GB total) full_year <- sipni_data(year = 2024, uf = "AC")

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
code: ac_2019 <- sipni_data(year = 2019, uf = "AC")  # decode immunobiological names imuno_labels <- sipni_dictionary("IMUNO") |>   select(code, label)  doses_by_vaccine <- ac_2019 |>   group_by(IMUNO) |>   summarize(total_doses = sum(as.integer(QT_DOSE), na.rm = TRUE),             .groups = "drop") |>   left_join(imuno_labels, by = c("IMUNO" = "code")) |>   arrange(desc(total_doses))  doses_by_vaccine

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
code: # coverage data for Sao Paulo, 2015-2019 sp_cov <- sipni_data(   year = 2015:2019,   type = "CPNI",   uf = "SP" )  # average coverage by year sp_cov |>   group_by(year) |>   summarize(     mean_coverage = mean(as.numeric(COBERT), na.rm = TRUE),     .groups = "drop"   )

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
code: # COVID-19 vaccinations in Acre, January 2024 ac_jan <- sipni_data(year = 2024, uf = "AC", month = 1)  # vaccines administered ac_jan |>   count(descricao_vacina, sort = TRUE)  # doses by sex ac_jan |>   count(tipo_sexo_paciente)  # age distribution ac_jan |>   mutate(age = as.integer(numero_idade_paciente)) |>   filter(!is.na(age)) |>   mutate(age_group = cut(age,                          breaks = c(0, 5, 12, 18, 30, 60, Inf),                          right = FALSE)) |>   count(age_group)

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
text: requesting years span sources (e.g., 2019 2024), sipni_data() fetches FTP CSV respectively combines results. Note column names structure differ sources:
code: # this downloads FTP (2019) + CSV (2024) mixed <- sipni_data(year = c(2019, 2024), uf = "AC", month = 1)  # columns from FTP (UPPERCASE) and CSV (snake_case) are combined # with NAs where columns don't overlap names(mixed)

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
text: FTP files (1994–2019) small (~100 KB ) download quickly. CSV files (2020+) large (~1.4 GB per month, national). Start single month UF. first download CSV month caches 27 UFs. second request different UF month instant cache. Multiple months downloaded concurrently possible.

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
code: # parsed types (default) ac <- sipni_data(year = 2019, uf = "AC") class(ac$QT_DOSE)  # integer  # raw character columns ac_raw <- sipni_data(year = 2019, uf = "AC", parse = FALSE)

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
text: Downloaded data cached locally faster future access: arrow package installed, data cached Parquet format. can also use lazy evaluation:
code: # check cache status sipni_cache_status()  # clear cache if needed sipni_clear_cache() # lazy query for FTP data (requires arrow) sipni_lazy <- sipni_data(year = 2019, uf = "AC", lazy = TRUE) sipni_lazy |>   filter(QT_DOSE > 0) |>   select(IMUNO, DOSE, QT_DOSE) |>   collect()

title: Vaccination Data with SI-PNI
text: SI-PNI official page (DATASUS) OpenDataSUS vaccination data National Immunization Program (PNI) Census vignette population denominators

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
text: SISAB (Sistema de Informacao em Saude para Atencao Basica) provides primary care coverage indicators Brazil, maintained Ministry Health (SAPS). Unlike DATASUS modules use FTP, SISAB data fetched public REST API.

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: sisab_years()

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: sisab_info()

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: # APS coverage by state, January 2024 aps_jan <- sisab_data(year = 2024, month = 1) aps_jan

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: # APS coverage, all months of 2023 aps_2023 <- sisab_data(year = 2023) aps_2023

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: sb <- sisab_data(year = 2024, type = "sb", month = 6) sb

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: acs <- sisab_data(year = 2023, type = "acs") acs

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: pns <- sisab_data(year = 2022, type = "pns") pns

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: national <- sisab_data(year = 2024, level = "brazil", month = 1) national

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: regions <- sisab_data(year = 2024, level = "region", month = 1) regions

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: states <- sisab_data(year = 2024, level = "uf", month = 1) states

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: # filter by UF to avoid large downloads sp_munic <- sisab_data(   year = 2024,   level = "municipality",   uf = "SP",   month = 1 ) sp_munic

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: # single state, single month sp_jan <- sisab_data(year = 2024, uf = "SP", month = 1)  # specific months sp_q1 <- sisab_data(year = 2024, uf = "SP", month = 1:3)  # multiple years sp_multi <- sisab_data(year = 2022:2024, uf = "SP", month = 6)

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: # APS variables (default) sisab_variables()  # oral health variables sisab_variables(type = "sb")  # community agents sisab_variables(type = "acs")  # PNS variables sisab_variables(type = "pns")  # search sisab_variables(search = "cobertura") sisab_variables(search = "equipe")

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: aps <- sisab_data(year = 2024, level = "uf", month = 6)  # coverage by state aps |>   select(sgUf, qtPopulacao, qtCobertura) |>   arrange(desc(qtCobertura))

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: # monthly APS coverage, national level, 2020-2024 trend <- sisab_data(   year = 2020:2024,   level = "brazil" )  trend |>   select(year, nuComp, qtCobertura) |>   arrange(year, nuComp)

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
code: # municipality-level APS coverage in Minas Gerais mg_munic <- sisab_data(   year = 2024,   level = "municipality",   uf = "MG",   month = 6 )  # distribution of coverage mg_munic |>   summarize(     n_municipalities = n(),     mean_coverage = mean(qtCobertura, na.rm = TRUE),     median_coverage = median(qtCobertura, na.rm = TRUE),     min_coverage = min(qtCobertura, na.rm = TRUE),     max_coverage = max(qtCobertura, na.rm = TRUE)   )

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
text: SISAB differences DATASUS FTP modules (SIM, SIH, CNES, etc.): Column names preserved returned API (e.g., qtCobertura, sgUf, noMunicipioIbge). Use sisab_variables() explore .

title: Primary Care Coverage with SISAB
text: Downloaded data cached locally faster future access:
code: # check cache status sisab_cache_status()  # clear cache if needed sisab_clear_cache()

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
text: healthbR provides easy access Brazilian public health data directly R. package downloads, caches, processes data official sources, returning clean, analysis-ready tibbles following tidyverse conventions.

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
text: DATASUS modules download .dbc files (compressed DBF) decompress internally using vendored C code – external dependencies required.

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
text: can install development version healthbR GitHub:
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("SidneyBissoli/healthbR")

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
code: library(healthbR)  # see all available data sources list_sources()

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
text: DATASUS modules follow consistent API: *_years(), *_info(), *_variables(), *_dictionary(), *_data(), *_cache_status(), *_clear_cache().
code: # mortality data -- deaths in Acre, 2022 obitos <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  # filter by cause of death (CID-10 prefix) obitos_cardio <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", cause = "I")  # live births in Acre, 2022 nascimentos <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  # hospital admissions in Acre, January 2022 internacoes <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # filter by diagnosis (CID-10 prefix) intern_resp <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")  # outpatient production in Acre, January 2022 ambulatorial <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # different file type (e.g., high-cost medications) medicamentos <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "AM")

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
code: # VIGITEL telephone survey vigitel <- vigitel_data(year = 2024)  # PNS national health survey pns <- pns_data(year = 2019)  # PNAD Continua pnadc <- pnadc_data(year = 2023, quarter = 1)  # POF household budget survey pof <- pof_data(year = 2018, register = "morador")  # Census population pop <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state")

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
code: # list variables for any module sim_variables() sia_variables(search = "sexo")  # data dictionary with category labels sim_dictionary("SEXO") sia_dictionary("PA_RACACOR")

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
text: modules cache downloaded data automatically. Install arrow optimized Parquet caching: module provides cache management functions:
code: install.packages("arrow") # check what is cached sim_cache_status() sih_cache_status() sia_cache_status()  # clear cache for a module sim_clear_cache()

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
text: data downloaded official Brazilian government repositories: VIGITEL: https://svs.aids.gov.br/daent/cgdnt/vigitel/ PNS / PNAD Continua / POF: https://www.ibge.gov.br/ Censo: SIDRA API (https://apisidra.ibge.gov.br/) SIM / SINASC / SIH / SIA: DATASUS FTP (ftp://ftp.datasus.gov.br/dissemin/publicos/)

title: Show ANS Cache Status — ans_cache_status

text: Deletes cached ANS data files.

title: Clear ANS Cache — ans_clear_cache

title: Clear ANS Cache — ans_clear_cache
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() ans_clear_cache() }

title: Download ANS Data — ans_data
text: Downloads returns data ANS (Agencia Nacional de Saude Suplementar) open data portal. Supports three data types: beneficiary counts, consumer complaints (NIP), financial statements.

title: Download ANS Data — ans_data
code: ans_data(   year,   type = "beneficiaries",   uf = NULL,   month = NULL,   quarter = NULL,   vars = NULL,   cache = TRUE,   cache_dir = NULL,   lazy = FALSE,   backend = c("arrow", "duckdb") )

title: Download ANS Data — ans_data
text: year Integer. Year(s) data. Required. type Character. Type data. One : "beneficiaries": Consolidated beneficiary counts (default). Uses year, month, uf parameters. "complaints": Consumer complaints via NIP. Uses year (national data). "financial": Financial statements. Uses year, quarter parameters. uf Character. Two-letter state abbreviation(s). used type = "beneficiaries". Includes "XX" unidentified beneficiaries. NULL (default), downloads 27 states. month Integer. Month(s) 1-12. used type = "beneficiaries". NULL (default), downloads months. Note: 2019 starts month 4 (April). quarter Integer. Quarter(s) 1-4. used type = "financial". NULL (default), downloads 4 quarters. vars Character vector. Variables keep. NULL (default), returns available variables. Use ans_variables() see available variables per type. cache Logical. TRUE (default), caches downloaded data faster future access. cache_dir Character. Directory caching. Default: tools::R_user_dir("healthbR", "cache"). lazy Logical. TRUE, returns lazy query object instead tibble. Requires arrow package. Default: FALSE. backend Character. Backend lazy evaluation: "arrow" (default) "duckdb". used lazy = TRUE.

title: Download ANS Data — ans_data
text: tibble ANS data. Includes partition columns: year (types), month uf_source (beneficiaries), quarter (financial).

title: Download ANS Data — ans_data
text: Data downloaded ANS open data portal https://dadosabertos.ans.gov.br/. Beneficiaries: Monthly per-state ZIP files containing CSV data consolidated beneficiary counts operator, plan type, sex, age group, municipality. Available April 2019. Complaints: Annual national CSV files consumer complaints filed NIP (Notificacao de Intermediacao Preliminar). Available 2011. Financial: Quarterly ZIP files financial statements health plan operators (balance sheets, income statements). Available 2007.

title: Download ANS Data — ans_data
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # beneficiary counts for Acre, December 2023 ac <- ans_data(year = 2023, month = 12, uf = "AC")  # consumer complaints for 2022 nip <- ans_data(year = 2022, type = "complaints")  # financial statements Q1 2023 fin <- ans_data(year = 2023, type = "financial", quarter = 1) }

title: ANS Module Information — ans_info
text: Displays information ANS (Agencia Nacional de Saude Suplementar) module, including data sources, available years, usage guidance.

title: ANS Module Information — ans_info
code: ans_info()

title: ANS Module Information — ans_info
text: list module information (invisibly).

title: ANS Module Information — ans_info
code: ans_info() #>  #> ── ANS — Agência Nacional de Saúde Suplementar ───────────────────────────────── #>  #> Fonte: Agência Nacional de Saúde Suplementar (ANS) #> Acesso: Dados Abertos ANS (HTTP) #> Conteúdo: Dados do setor de saúde suplementar (planos de saúde) #>  #> ── Dados disponíveis ── #>  #> • `ans_data()`: Dados de beneficiários, demandas e demonstrações contábeis #> • `ans_operators()`: Cadastro de operadoras (ativas/canceladas) #> • `ans_variables()`: Lista de variáveis disponíveis #>  #> ── Tipos de dados ── #>  #> beneficiaries Beneficiários — Informações consolidadas de beneficiários por #> operadora, UF, sexo, faixa etária #> complaints Demandas dos consumidores (NIP) — Demandas e reclamações de #> consumidores via NIP #> financial Demonstrações contábeis — Demonstrações contábeis trimestrais das #> operadoras #>  #> ── Parâmetros por tipo ── #>  #> beneficiaries: year, month, uf #> complaints: year #> financial: year, quarter #>  #> ── Períodos disponíveis ── #>  #> Beneficiários: Abr/2019–2025 (mensal, por UF) #> Demandas NIP: 2011–2026 (anual, nacional) #> Demonstrações: 2007–2025 (trimestral) #> Operadoras: Instantaneo (cadastro atual) #>

title: Download ANS Operators Registry — ans_operators
text: Downloads returns current registry health plan operators ANS open data portal. snapshot current operator status (time-series data).

title: Download ANS Operators Registry — ans_operators
code: ans_operators(status = "active", vars = NULL, cache = TRUE, cache_dir = NULL)

title: Download ANS Operators Registry — ans_operators
text: status Character. Filter operator status: "active": Active operators (default). "cancelled": Cancelled operators . "": active cancelled. vars Character vector. Variables keep. NULL (default), returns 20 variables. Use ans_variables(type = "operators") see available variables. cache Logical. TRUE (default), caches downloaded data. cache_dir Character. Directory caching.

title: Download ANS Operators Registry — ans_operators
text: tibble operator data. status = "", includes status column indicating "active" "cancelled".

title: Download ANS Operators Registry — ans_operators
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # active operators ops <- ans_operators()  # all operators (active + cancelled) all_ops <- ans_operators(status = "all") }

title: List ANS Variables — ans_variables

title: Download ANVISA Data — anvisa_data
text: Downloads returns data ANVISA (Agencia Nacional de Vigilancia Sanitaria) open data portal. Supports 14 data types across 4 categories: product registrations, reference tables, post-market surveillance, controlled substance sales (SNGPC).

title: Download ANVISA Data — anvisa_data
code: anvisa_data(   type = "medicines",   year = NULL,   month = NULL,   vars = NULL,   cache = TRUE,   cache_dir = NULL,   lazy = FALSE,   backend = c("arrow", "duckdb") )

title: Download ANVISA Data — anvisa_data
text: type Character. Type data download. Default: "medicines". Use anvisa_types() see 14 available types. Snapshot types (year/month needed): "medicines", "medical_devices", "food", "cosmetics", "sanitizers", "tobacco", "pesticides", "hemovigilance", "technovigilance", "vigimed_notifications", "vigimed_medicines", "vigimed_reactions". Time-series types (year required): "sngpc", "sngpc_compounded". year Integer. Year(s) data. used SNGPC types (2014-2026). Ignored warning snapshot types. month Integer. Month(s) 1-12. used SNGPC types. NULL (default), downloads 12 months. Ignored warning snapshot types. vars Character vector. Variables keep. NULL (default), returns available variables. Use anvisa_variables() see available variables per type. cache Logical. TRUE (default), caches downloaded data faster future access. cache_dir Character. Directory caching. Default: tools::R_user_dir("healthbR", "cache"). lazy Logical. TRUE, returns lazy query object instead tibble. available SNGPC types (partitioned cache). Requires arrow package. Default: FALSE. backend Character. Backend lazy evaluation: "arrow" (default) "duckdb". used lazy = TRUE.

title: Download ANVISA Data — anvisa_data
text: tibble ANVISA data. SNGPC types include year month partition columns.

title: Download ANVISA Data — anvisa_data
text: Data downloaded ANVISA open data portal https://dados.anvisa.gov.br/dados/. Snapshot types: Download single CSV file representing current state registry/database. time dimension. Cached flat files. SNGPC types: Monthly CSV files controlled substance sales data. Data available January 2014 October 2021, new data January 2026. Cached Hive-style partitioned parquet datasets. three VigiMed types share IDENTIFICACAO_NOTIFICACAO key linking notifications, medicines, reactions.

title: Download ANVISA Data — anvisa_data
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # registered medicines med <- anvisa_data(type = "medicines")  # hemovigilance notifications hemo <- anvisa_data(type = "hemovigilance")  # SNGPC controlled substance sales, Jan 2020 sngpc <- anvisa_data(type = "sngpc", year = 2020, month = 1) }

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
text: Retrieves population data Brazilian Demographic Census via SIDRA API. Automatically selects correct SIDRA table based year requested variables.

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
code: censo_populacao(   year,   variables = "total",   territorial_level = "state",   geo_code = "all",   raw = FALSE )

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
text: year Numeric. Census year (1970, 1980, 1991, 2000, 2010, 2022). variables Character. Type breakdown: "total": Total population "sex": sex (male/female) "age": age groups "age_sex": age groups sex "race": race/color (2000, 2010, 2022) "situation": urban/rural situation Default "total". territorial_level Character. Geographic level: "brazil", "region", "state", "municipality". Default "state". geo_code Character. IBGE code(s) specific localities. "" returns localities chosen level. Default "". raw Logical. TRUE, returns raw API output without cleaning. Default FALSE.

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
text: tibble population data.

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
text: function provides easy interface common Census queries. automatically resolves correct SIDRA table: Table 200: Historical population 1970-2010 (sex, age, situation) Table 9514: Census 2022 population sex age Table 136: Population race 2000-2010 Table 9605: Population race 2022 Table 9515: Population urban/rural 2022 flexibility, use censo_sidra_data query table custom parameters.

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
text: Data retrieved IBGE SIDRA API: https://sidra.ibge.gov.br/

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # total population by state, 2022 censo_populacao(year = 2022)  # population by sex, Brazil level censo_populacao(year = 2022, variables = "sex", territorial_level = "brazil")  # population by age and sex, 2010 censo_populacao(year = 2010, variables = "age_sex")  # population by race, 2022 censo_populacao(year = 2022, variables = "race") }

what: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
title: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
text: Queries IBGE SIDRA API retrieve Census table. flexible function, allowing full control SIDRA query parameters.

title: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
code: censo_sidra_data(   table,   territorial_level = "brazil",   geo_code = "all",   year = NULL,   variable = NULL,   classifications = NULL,   raw = FALSE )

title: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
text: table Numeric character. SIDRA table code. Use censo_sidra_tables censo_sidra_search find codes. territorial_level Character. Geographic level: "brazil" (N1), "region" (N2), "state" (N3), "municipality" (N6). Default "brazil". geo_code Character. IBGE code(s) specific localities. "" returns localities chosen level. Default "". year Numeric character. Year(s) query. NULL returns available periods. variable Numeric character. SIDRA variable ID(s). NULL returns variables excluding metadata. Default NULL. classifications Named list. SIDRA classification filters. Example: list("2" = "allxt") sex breakdown. NULL returns default aggregation. Default NULL. raw Logical. TRUE, returns raw API output without cleaning. Default FALSE.

title: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
text: tibble queried data.

title: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # population by state from 2022 Census censo_sidra_data(   table = 9514,   territorial_level = "state",   year = 2022,   variable = 93 )  # population by race, Brazil level censo_sidra_data(   table = 9605,   territorial_level = "brazil",   year = 2022,   variable = 93,   classifications = list("86" = "allxt") ) }
